revision.comment: per [[WT:NORM]], ensure "No […] whitespace at the […] end of a line"
revision.text: {{also|yat|yát|þat}} ==English== ===Etymology=== From the phrase "where y'at?" (i.e. "where are you at?"), akin to the greeting "[[how are you]]?". ===Proper noun=== {{en-proper noun}} # A unique collection of dialects of English spoken in [[New Orleans]], Louisiana. #* '''1996''', Thomas Burns McArthur, Roshan McArthur, ''The Oxford Companion to the English Language'', Oxford University Press, USA ({{ISBN|9780198631361}}) #*: The most distinctive local variety is '''Yat''', called by one observer 'the Cockney of New Orleans'. #* '''2006''', ''Lonely Planet New Orleans'' #*: Traces of New Orleans' old '''Yat''' dialect are still heard around town. Apart from city-specific expressions, '''Yat''' sounds an awful lot like the traditional Brooklyn accent, and it reflects the same Irish, Italian and German roots. ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # A person of the New Orleans, Louisiana area who speaks with a Yat accent. ===Further reading=== * {{pedia|New Orleans English}} ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=aty|AYT|Tay|tay}}
